questions.prompt: 1. In BG 18.1, what is the central question Arjuna asks?
choices: O Krishna, please explain the distinction between renunciation and the relinquishment of the fruit of action
questions.feedback: Arjuna seeks clarity on true renunciation versus mere abandonment of action.

questions.prompt: 2. In BG 18.2-4, what does Krishna clarify about renunciation?
choices: Renunciation is acting without attachment to results; performing duties without ego
questions.feedback: True renunciation is detachment, not inaction.

questions.prompt: 3. In BG 18.3-5, what is the definition of renunciation according to the wise?
choices: Renouncing the fruits of action but not action itself; performing duty as service to God
questions.feedback: Renunciation means detachment from results, not abandonment of action.

questions.prompt: 4. In BG 18.5-6, what is karma (action) called?
choices: Work that is necessary; it can be auspicious or inauspicious
questions.feedback: All action has consequences; attachment to action binds, detachment liberates.

questions.prompt: 5. In BG 18.6, what is the best renunciation?
choices: Renouncing the fruits of all actions; giving up attachment and ego
questions.feedback: Internal detachment is the highest form of renunciation.

questions.prompt: 6. In BG 18.8-11, what are the three types of karma?
choices: Sattvic (pure duty), rajasic (passionate action), and tamasic (ignorant action)
questions.feedback: All action falls into one of the three modes of nature.

questions.prompt: 7. In BG 18.9, what characterizes sattvic action?
choices: Performed without attachment, without ego, without craving for results
questions.feedback: Sattvic action is pure duty performed in Krishna consciousness.

questions.prompt: 8. In BG 18.10, what characterizes rajasic action?
choices: Performed with ego, attachment, and desire for results
questions.feedback: Rajasic action binds the performer to material consequences.

questions.prompt: 9. In BG 18.11, what characterizes tamasic action?
choices: Performed in delusion, without considering consequences or capacity
questions.feedback: Tamasic action creates confusion and bondage.

questions.prompt: 10. In BG 18.12-16, what are the three types of knowledge?
choices: Sattvic (universal, eternal truth), rajasic (limited and partial), tamasic (delusion)
questions.feedback: Knowledge also manifests in the three modes.

questions.prompt: 11. In BG 18.12, what characterizes sattvic knowledge?
choices: Perceiving the unity in diversity; understanding eternity in all beings
questions.feedback: Sattvic knowledge reveals the eternal soul and divine reality.

questions.prompt: 12. In BG 18.13, what characterizes rajasic knowledge?
choices: Concerned with specific results and various multifarious beings; limited perspective
questions.feedback: Rajasic knowledge sees differences and focuses on varied results.

questions.prompt: 13. In BG 18.14, what characterizes tamasic knowledge?
choices: Attached to one activity; narrow-minded, ignorant, and deceptive
questions.feedback: Tamasic knowledge is confused and limited.

questions.prompt: 14. In BG 18.17-19, what are the three types of determination/steadiness?
choices: Sattvic (steady, focused on yoga), rajasic (attached to results), tamasic (dull, confused)
questions.feedback: Determination also reflects the three modes of nature.

questions.prompt: 15. In BG 18.20-22, what is the dharma (duty) system based on?
choices: The four varnas (classes): brahmins, kshatriyas, vaishyas, shudras, based on nature and qualities
questions.feedback: The varna system divides society by nature and occupational duty.

questions.prompt: 16. In BG 18.41-44, what is the duty of a brahmin?
choices: Self-control, purity, ascetic practice, knowledge, and service to God
questions.feedback: Brahmins are devoted to spiritual and intellectual development.

questions.prompt: 17. In BG 18.43, what is the duty of a kshatriya?
choices: Bravery, heroism, patience, fighting ability, generosity, and leadership
questions.feedback: Kshatriyas protect society through courage and righteous action.

questions.prompt: 18. In BG 18.44, what is the duty of a vaishya and shudra?
choices: Vaishyas: agriculture, trade, and cattle; Shudras: service to others
questions.feedback: Vaishyas and shudras have specific material and service duties.

questions.prompt: 19. In BG 18.45-46, how does one achieve perfection?
choices: By performing one's own dharma (duty) with devotion to Krishna; not by attempting others' duties
questions.feedback: Perfection comes from faithful performance of one's natural duty.

questions.prompt: 20. In BG 18.47-48, what is the result of performing one's own duty?
choices: One achieves perfection and liberation; flaws in duty are preferable to another's perfection
questions.feedback: Duty performed with devotion leads to spiritual perfection.

questions.prompt: 21. In BG 18.50-55, what is the ultimate yoga or perfection?
choices: Devotion to Krishna; surrender to God and realizing Krishna as the goal of all knowledge
questions.feedback: Bhakti yoga—pure devotion to Krishna—is the highest perfection.

questions.prompt: 22. In BG 18.62, what does Krishna advise Arjuna regarding his dilemma?
choices: Take refuge in Krishna alone; surrender to Him for guidance and protection
questions.feedback: Surrender to Krishna is the ultimate solution to all confusion.

questions.prompt: 23. In BG 18.66, what is Krishna's final instruction?
choices: Abandon all varieties of religion and surrender unto Me; I will protect you from all sinful reactions
questions.feedback: Surrender to Krishna is the ultimate instruction for liberation.

questions.prompt: 24. In BG 18.73-78, what was Arjuna's final decision?
choices: To fight in full consciousness of Krishna; his confusion was dispelled by Krishna's teachings
questions.feedback: Arjuna resolved to fight righteously, surrendered to Krishna.

questions.prompt: 25. In BG 18 (complete teaching), what is the highest message?
choices: Through bhakti (devotion), perform your duty, and surrender to Krishna—this is the path to eternal liberation
questions.feedback: Chapter 18 synthesizes the entire Bhagavad-gita: duty, knowledge, and devotion culminating in surrender to Krishna.
